questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the obstetrician with her partner for evaluation of infertility. The patient has had three prior pregnancies, all of which ended in miscarriages during the first trimester. She currently has monthly menstrual periods. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is an avid runner and takes part in several marathons each year. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and body mass index is 21 kg/m2. Speculum examination reveals a normal-appearing cervix. The abdomen is soft and nondistended, and there are no palpable masses. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a prothrombin time of 12 seconds and partial thromboplastin time of 37 seconds. A hysterosalpingogram is performed and shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Complete failure of Müllerian duct fusion
Proliferation of benign uterine smooth muscle tumors
Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of recurrent miscarriages. Laboratory testing is unremarkable and imagining reveals a bicornuate uterus. This condition arises due to incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts.    

Uterine anomalies describe anatomical malformations of the uterus that are present at birth.    

A septate uterus occurs when the Müllerian ducts fuse, but the septum between the ducts persists. The condition can lead to decreased fertility and increased risk of early miscarriage or pregnancy loss. Diagnosis can be made with imaging techniques (e.g., ultrasound, hysterosalpingogram, MRI) revealing the presence of a midline septum.  

A bicornuate uterus occurs due to incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts. As a result, the uterus develops two upper horns above the uterine body, giving it a heart shape. The finding can be observed on imaging. The condition can lead to an increased risk of complicated pregnancy, fetal malpresentation, early miscarriage, and preterm birth.    

Finally, uterus didelphys occurs due to complete failure of Müllerian duct fusion. As a result, patients will have a double uterus, double cervix, and double vagina. While pregnancy remains possible, patients are at increased risk of early miscarriage and preterm birth. Imaging will reveal two uncommunicated uteruses, each one with its own fallopian tube.  



Option Analysis

❌ Complete failure of Müllerian duct fusion:
Incorrect: Uterus didelphys occurs when there is complete failure in fusion of the Müllerian ducts. As a result, individuals will have two uteruses, two cervixes, and two vaginas. In contrast, this patient’s imaging demonstrates a single vagina and cervix but two uteruses, which is more suggestive of a bicornuate uterus.  
❌ Proliferation of benign uterine smooth muscle tumors:
Incorrect: Uterine fibroids are caused by benign proliferation of smooth muscle. The condition can lead to recurrent miscarriages. However, fibroids are neither present on physical examination nor imaging, and the patient lacks additional symptoms suggestive of fibroids (e.g., menorrhagia, back pain).  
❌ Formation of anti-β2 glycoprotein autoantibodies:
Incorrect: Individuals with antiphospholipid syndrome can form anti-β2 glycoprotein autoantibodies and are at risk for recurrent miscarriages. The condition will lead to an elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT). In contrast, this patient’s PTT is within normal limits, making antiphospholipid syndrome unlikely. 
✅ Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced hypothalamic hormone release:
Incorrect: Excessive exercise can lead to reduced hypothalamic secretion of GnRH, which subsequently impairs pituitary release of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). The condition can manifest with amenorrhea and infertility. While this patient has a history of training for marathons, her BMI is within normal limits, and she has been having monthly menstrual periods. Furthermore, imaging findings are more suggestive of a uterine abnormality as the underlying cause of her prior miscarriages.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to a primary care physician for evaluation of worsening gynecomastia for three years. The patient smokes marijuana regularly but does not take medications for any underlying medical conditions. Examination reveals a well-appearing male with Tanner IV breast tissue, Tanner V pubic hair and a 5 cm mobile mass superior to the left gonad. The patient’s right gonad is not palpable. The patient noticed the mass one year prior, but thought it was normal and never sought evaluation. An ultrasound is conducted, which reveals a cystic mass with fluid levels. A biopsy is conducted, revealing seminiferous tubules with small round Sertoli cells and both primordial follicles and follicular cells. Which of the following is an additional clinical finding to be expected with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a testicular mass containing follicular cells. This finding is pathognomonic for an ovotesticular disorder – a rare disease arising from errors in gene expression regulating sexual development.

Sexual development occurs in two stages: the initial phase of sex determination, followed by sexual differentiation. Initially, inheritance of the Y chromosome and expression of its genetic content drives development of the gonad towards testicle formation. In the second phase of sexual differentiation, the secretion of growth factors and intercellular paracrine signalling (driven by the genes listed in the above table) drives external genital development and maturation. The secretion of testosterone and anti-mullerian factor by Leydig and Sertoli cells, respectively, induces development of the male sexual organs.

Patients with ovotesticular disorder have formerly been characterized as true hermaphrodites (note that although still widely used, this is now considered a pejorative term). Most patients are found to have ambiguous genitalia at birth. Phenotypic males present with cryptorchidism and hypospadia, later progressing to scrotal pain and gynecomastia during puberty. Phenotypic females present with labial fusion and urogenital sinus, later presenting with primary amenorrhea and infertility.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ambiguous genitalia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Imperforate hymen  :
Incorrect: Imperforate hymen refers to a congenital condition where the hymen completely obstructs the vagina.  
❌ Bifid uterus:
Incorrect: Also known as a bicornuate uterus, this is a congenital condition where the uterus is divided into two separate chambers. This condition is associated with preterm labor, recurrent miscarriage, and fetal malpresentation.  
❌ Labial hypoplasia:
Incorrect: Labial hypoplasia is a developmental abnormality where one labia is smaller or absent compared to the other. Labial hypoplasia is often corrected with cosmetic surgery and is not associated with other disorders of sexual development.  
❌ Testicular cancer  :
Incorrect: Although this patient presents with a lump on the superior pole of his testicle, it’s important to consider the results of the biopsy specimen, which reveals ovarian tissue within the testicle – suggesting an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for the evaluation of abdominal pain. The pain started approximately 6 months ago and has progressively worsened over time. It recurs every month around the same time and lasts for 2-3 days. The patient has not had a menstrual period yet but is otherwise healthy.  She has never been involved in vaginal, digital or oral sexual activity. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a well-appearing female of normal stature with Tanner stage III breast and pubic hair growth. Pelvic and rectal examination reveal a palpable mass anterior to the rectum which is obstructing the vagina. Pregnancy test is negative; thyroid stimulating hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are normal. The uterus and ovaries appear normal on ultrasound.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s abdominal pain?

choices.text: Failed canalization of external vaginal membrane

questions.solution:
This patient with monthly cyclical abdominal pain, normal secondary sexual characteristics in the absence of menstruation, in combination with a vaginal bulge, most likely has an imperforate hymen.

An imperforate hymen is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to failed canalization of the hymen, the membrane covering the vaginal opening, during embryological development. The condition can sometimes be diagnosed at birth, when the vaginal secretions stimulated by maternal estrogen cause a mucocolpos in the infant. However, it may remain undiagnosed or asymptomatic until after menarche, when the patient reports cyclic abdominal or pelvic pain in the absence of menses. The collection of blood (hematocolpos) and mucous behind the vaginal introitus, can cause back pain and difficulty with defecation. The patients have normal internal reproductive organs and secondary sexual characteristics. Physical examination shows a vaginal bulge or a palpable anterior rectal mass.



Option Analysis

❌ Failed follicle maturation:
Incorrect: The imbalance of LH/FSH ratio in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can result in the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. PCOS is characterized by hyperandrogenic characteristics (e.g. acne and hirsutism) and/or elevated testosterone levels. Menstrual irregularities and infertility can also be seen. Ovaries appear polycystic on ultrasound.
❌ Severe calorie restriction and deficiency:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea occurs in females with severe calorie restriction and nutrient deficiency due to the suppression of hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. FSH and LH are low in this condition. This patient’s FSH and LH are within normal limits.
✅ Failed canalization of external vaginal membrane:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Failed development of Müllerian duct:
Incorrect: Müllerian agenesis results from the failure of Müllerian duct development. The uterus, cervix and upper two-thirds of vagina are absent in these patients. This patient has a normal uterus.
❌ Obstruction of Bartholin gland duct:
Incorrect: Obstruction of the Bartholin gland duct can present as a unilateral, palpable mass in the posterior vaginal introitus. The cyclical abdominal pain in this patient, however, is suggestive of imperforate hymen.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to her family physician with concerns regarding delayed sexual development. The patient states that she has never had a menstrual cycle. Her temperature is 98.6 F° (37C°), blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and heart rate is 90/min. On pelvic examination, the patient is found to have absence of pubic hair, bilateral intra-labial masses, and a blind-end vaginal pouch. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient who identifies as a female presents with a blind-ended vaginal canal, intra-labial testicles, and a lack of pubic hair. These findings are indicative of a hormonal deficiency during development, specifically of androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS).

AIS is a disorder that arises secondary to defective androgen receptors. Androgens are created in the testes and adrenal gland and subsequently enter systemic circulation. They are then internalized into multiple cell types throughout the body via androgen receptors where they execute transcriptional activities that promote phenotypic masculinization. A mutation of the androgen receptor silences this process, arresting phenotypic masculinization, resulting in de-facto development of female phenotypic characteristics. An important component of management of this condition involves gonadectomy, as retained undeveloped testes carry a risk of malignant transformation.  



Option Analysis

✅ Defective androgen receptors  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chromosomal mosaicism  :
Incorrect: Chromosomal mosaicism is characteristic of Turner syndrome, which results in females lacking an X chromosome. Clinical features include short stature, delayed puberty, infertility, heart defects, and learning disabilities.  
❌ Deficiency of placental aromatase  :
Incorrect: Placental aromatase deficiency results in an accumulation of circulating androgens in both the maternal and fetal circulation. In the female fetus, excess circulating androgens result in the development of ambiguous female genitalia.  
❌ 5-alpha-reductase deficiency  :
Incorrect: 5-alpha-reductase deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder of sexual development caused by a mutation in the SRD5A2 gene. 5-alpha-reductase deficiency results in the inability to convert testosterone to its more potent form, dihydrotestosterone.  
❌ Aberration of GnRH neuronal migration  :
Incorrect: Kallmann syndrome, a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, is characterized by anosmia and lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to aberrant neuronal migration of GnRH-releasing neurons in the olfactory placode.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to his family physician for a routine school physical. The patient appears anxious and uneasy during the encounter. During the physical exam, the patient confesses that he feels insecure about his body. During gym practice, the patient has noticed that his genitalia appears different from his peers. There is no history of a disorder of sexual development within the family. The patient’s height and weight are at the 56<sup>th</sup> and 45<sup>th</sup> percentile for his age, respectively. On physical examination, ambiguous genitalia are present with a bifid scrotum, undescended testicles and hypospadias. Laboratory testing reveals an increased testosterone to dihydrotestosterone ratio. Which of the following is likely true regarding this patient’s parents?

choices.text: The patient’s father is homozygous recessive.
Neither parent possesses an allele for the disease.
The patient’s mother is homozygous dominant.

questions.solution:
On exam, this patient is found to have ambiguous genitalia, a bifid scrotum, hypospadias, and undescended testicles, which point to a disorder of sexual development (DSD). While DSDs encompass a large family of conditions, this patient’s elevated testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) level is indicative of 5-alpha-reductase deficiency.

The ratio of increased testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) indicates this patient’s inability to convert testosterone to its more potent form, DHT. The enzyme responsible for this conversion is 5-alpha reductase. A mutation of this enzyme is caused by a mutation of the SRD5A2 gene, which is inherited in an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.  

Option Analysis

❌ Both parents are homozygous recessive.  :
Incorrect: The vignette states that there is no history of a disorder of sexual development in the family. If both parents were homozygous recessive, the father would present with symptoms of 5-alpha-reductase deficiency.  
✅ Both parents are heterozygous.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The patient’s father is homozygous recessive.  :
Incorrect: The vignette states that there is no history of a disorder of sexual development in the family. If the patient's father were homozygous recessive, he would present with symptoms of 5-alpha-reductase deficiency.  
❌ Neither parent possesses an allele for the disease.  :
Incorrect: This patient is suffering from 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, which is an autosomal recessive disease.  
❌ The patient’s mother is homozygous dominant.  :
Incorrect: 5-alpha-reductase deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder. If one parent is homozygous dominant, it would be impossible for him to inherit the disease.

questions.text: A 19-year-old primigravid woman at 14-weeks of gestation presents for evaluation with a painful, pruritic rash. The rash developed four days ago, was initially localized to the trunk, and subsequently spread to the extremities. She has not experienced pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, or unusual discharge. The patient works as a babysitter, and one of the children in her care developed a fever and a rash a week ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and pulse is 88/min. The patient’s blood type of O-. Physical examination reveals a vesicular, tender rash distributed over the chest, upper abdomen, and arms. Rubella and varicella titers from a prenatal visit three weeks ago were negative. Which of the physical examination findings will most likely be observed in the patient’s child after delivery?

choices.text: Continuous murmur over the left second intercostal space
Mass within the posterior triangle of the neck
Punched out a lesion on the scalp

questions.solution:
This patient has a fever and a painful, vesicular rash. These findings are concerning for varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection. The virus can be vertically transmitted to the unborn child and cause congenital varicella syndrome, manifesting with limb hypoplasia.

Maternal varicella infection is acquired via infected nasopharyngeal secretions or direct contact with skin lesions. Women who are unvaccinated or have no prior history of VZV infection are at risk of being infected. Maternal infection initially presents with fever, malaise, and myalgia. After several days, a characteristic pruritic, vesicular rash will appear on the face, trunk, and extremities.

The virus can subsequently cross the placenta and infect the fetus. Involvement of the fetal dorsal root ganglion can lead to the destruction of nerve tissue, thereby resulting in the denervation changes seen in congenital varicella syndrome. Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cutaneous scars with a dermatomal distribution, neurological abnormalities (e.g., microcephaly, mental retardation, seizures, hydrocephalus), and ocular abnormalities (e.g., optic nerve atrophy, chorioretinitis), and limb abnormalities (e.g., hypoplasia, atrophy, paresis).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hypoplasia of both lower extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Continuous murmur over the left second intercostal space:
Incorrect: A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a left to right shunt that can be clinically identified by a continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region with maximum intensity at S2. A PDA is associated with a congenital rubella infection. In contrast, this patient likely has varicella-zoster, and her fetus is at risk of congenital varicella syndrome. Congenital varicella syndrome would not typically result in a PDA.  
❌ Diffuse swelling of the skin:
Incorrect: Fetal infection by parvovirus B19 can result in hydrops fetalis, which manifests with diffuse skin swelling, abdominal ascites, pleural effusions, and pericardial effusion. Maternal infection by parvovirus can cause symmetrical arthralgias. However, it would not cause the painful and pruritic rash present in this patient.  
❌ Mass within the posterior triangle of the neck:
Incorrect: Cystic hygromas can present as a mass in the posterior triangle of the neck. The condition is often present in patients with Turner syndrome (45 XO karyotype). Other common features associated with Turner syndrome include edema of the extremities and coarctation of the aorta. In contrast, cystic hygromas are not associated with in utero exposure to the varicella-zoster virus.  
❌ Punched out a lesion on the scalp:
Incorrect: Cutis aplasia, characterized by focal cutaneous defects of the scalp, is associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy of chromosome 13) and in utero exposure to methimazole. In contrast, this patient likely has varicella-zoster, and her fetus is at risk of congenital varicella syndrome. Congenital varicella syndrome would not typically result in cutis aplasia.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old male infant is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit after two episodes of seizures. The patient was delivered via vaginal delivery at 37-weeks gestational age. The mother received minimal prenatal care and experienced a flu-like illness and pharyngitis in the second trimester. Birth weight and head circumference are at the 20th percentile. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 84/52 mmHg, and pulse is 100/min. Physical examination is notable for petechiae and purpura over the arms, trunk, and legs. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Neuroimaging reveals the findings below. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely present in this patient?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Hemorrhage and necrosis of the retina
Continuous murmur over the left second intercostal space

questions.solution:
This neonate has seizures and hepatosplenomegaly. CT imaging of the brain reveals periventricular calcifications. In combination, these findings suggest congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. The pathogen can also cause chorioretinitis, which manifests with hemorrhage and necrosis of the retina on fundoscopic examination.

CMV is an enveloped DNA virus usually transmitted via sexual contact and less commonly via respiratory droplets or organ transplantation. Maternal infection presents mononucleosis-like symptoms such as fever, pharyngitis, fatigue, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. However, a heterophile antibody test will return negative.

Congenital CMV infection is acquired transplacentally and is asymptomatic in most infants. If symptomatic, neonates may present with petechiae and a blueberry muffin rash. Other hallmark features include progressive and permanent deafness, chorioretinitis (inflammation of the choroid and retina), and hepatosplenomegaly. Furthermore, congenital CMV infection can also affect the brain, causing seizures, intellectual disability, and microcephaly.

In affected patients, neuroimaging would reveal periventricular intracranial calcifications and ventriculomegaly. Biopsy of infected tissue will reveal intranuclear inclusion bodies with a surrounding halo, which have an “owl’s eye” appearance.
 

Intranuclear inclusion bodies in neural tissue seen in cytomegalovirus infection
Image reproduced from CDC Public Health Image Library 
  



Option Analysis

✅ Hemorrhage and necrosis of the retina:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Continuous murmur over the left second intercostal space:
Incorrect: A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a left to right shunt that can be clinically identified by a continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region with maximum intensity at S2. A PDA is associated with a congenital rubella infection. In contrast, this patient has seizures and periventricular calcifications, which are more suggestive of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.  
❌ Diffuse swelling of the skin:
Incorrect: Fetal infection by parvovirus B19 can result in hydrops fetalis, which manifests with diffuse skin swelling, abdominal ascites, pleural effusions, and pericardial effusion. However, infection by this pathogen would not typically cause seizures and periventricular calcifications.  
❌ Bilateral loss of red reflex:
Incorrect: Congenital rubella infection can cause the formation of cataracts, which would lead to a loss of the red reflex. In addition, congenital rubella infection can present with sensorineural hearing loss and heart defects. However, it would not typically cause seizures and periventricular calcifications.  
❌ Anterior bowing of the tibia:
Incorrect: Congenital infection by the spirochete Treponema pallidum can lead to anterior bowing of the tibia. This finding is termed “saber shins”. Congenital syphilis can also cause generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, maculopapular rash, hepatosplenomegaly, and dental deformities. In contrast, this patient’s seizures and periventricular calcifications suggest congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

questions.text: A 1 month-old girl is brought to the clinic for a routine evaluation. The patient was delivered via a cesarean at 38-weeks gestational age due to arrested labor. The mother immigrated from Zambia ten months ago and received minimal prenatal care. During the first trimester of pregnancy, she developed an upper respiratory infection and self-limited joint pain affecting the wrists, knees, and ankles. Family history is notable for retinitis pigmentosa. The patient’s weight is at the 20<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is at the 50<sup>th</sup> percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. She does not move her head in response to sounds. Facial features appear normal. Physical examination is notable for petechiae and purpura over the arms, trunk, and legs. A cardiac examination reveals a continuous murmur heard in the left infraclavicular area. Abdominal examination is notable for hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following findings is most likely present on this patient’s ophthalmologic examination?

choices.text: Presence of leukocytes within the vitreous humor
Bone spicule-shaped deposits around the macula

questions.solution:
This neonate has hearing loss, a murmur suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus, a blueberry muffin rash, and hepatosplenomegaly. Furthermore, the patient’s mother experienced fever and arthralgias during the pregnancy. In combination, these findings suggest congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

Rubella is caused by the rubella virus, an RNA virus transmitted via respiratory droplets and contact with nasopharyngeal secretions. Unvaccinated individuals are at the greatest risk of acquiring the infection. The pathogen replicates in lymphatic tissue and spreads hematogenously. Maternal rubella infection can present with a flu-like illness, arthralgias, maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalocaudal manner, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

Rubella can spread transplacentally during pregnancy and result in severe fetal complications, including premature labor, intrauterine fetal demise, spontaneous abortion, and congenital rubella syndrome. Congenital rubella syndrome is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, congenital cataracts, and congenital heart defects. The most common heart defects associated with congenital rubella syndrome are patent ductus arteriosus, a continuous murmur in the second intercostal space, and pulmonary artery stenosis. Other nonspecific clinical manifestations include microcephaly, blueberry muffin rash, and hepatosplenomegaly.
 

Cataract in congenital rubella syndrome
Image reproduced from CDC Public health image library 

Option Analysis

✅ Absent red reflex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement:
Incorrect: Retinal vein occlusion is characterized by retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement, which leads to a “blood and thunder” appearance. The condition tends to develop in older individuals with hypertension, atherosclerosis, and diabetes. In contrast, it would be unusual for a retinal vein occlusion to develop in neonates.  
❌ Retinal tears:
Incorrect: Retinal detachment is characterized by the separation of the neurosensory layer of the retina. The condition can present with acute vision loss and retinal tears on fundoscopy. The risk of retinal detachment increases with age. However, the condition is not associated with congenital rubella syndrome.  
❌ Presence of leukocytes within the vitreous humor:
Incorrect: Chorioretinitis is a type of uveitis affecting the posterior segment of the eye. Physical examination may reveal the presence of leukocytes within the vitreous tumor and signs of retinal inflammation (e.g. perivascular white spots, edema). Chorioretinitis can be caused by in utero Toxoplasma gondii and cytomegalovirus infection. However, it is not typically associated with congenital rubella syndrome.  
❌ Bone spicule-shaped deposits around the macula:
Incorrect: Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited degenerative condition that leads to painless, progressive vision loss. The condition initially manifests with night blindness. Although this neonate has a family history of retinitis pigmentosa, the associated symptoms of hearing loss and a congenital heart defect are more suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: A 21-day-old male infant is brought to the clinic for a routine evaluation. He was born at home via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 38-weeks gestational age. The patient’s mother did not receive antenatal care. The patient’s weight is at the 20th percentile, and head circumference is at the 40th percentile. Anterior fontanelle is open. The child does not move his head to sound. Facial features appear normal. Physical examination is notable for petechiae and purpura over the arms, trunk, and legs. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral cataracts. A cardiac examination reveals a continuous murmur heard in the left infraclavicular area. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly.  Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cataracts, hearing loss, hepatosplenomegaly, a murmur suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus, and a “blueberry muffin” rash. He likely has congenital rubella syndrome.

Infections can be transmitted from mother to fetus in utero via the placenta or during and after birth via blood, body fluids, or breast milk. These infections are collectively termed vertically transmitted infections. The common vertically transmitted infections are known as TORCH infections. They include Toxoplasma gondii, Other infections (Listeria monocytogenes, Treponema pallidum, parvovirus, HIV, VZV), Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and HSV 1 and 2.

Neonates should be evaluated for TORCH infections due to factors present in the maternal history. Potential risk factors include a positive syphilis serology, exposure to cat feces, or a history of sexually transmitted diseases.

Neonates affected by TORCH pathogens in utero may present nonspecific signs, including a blueberry muffin rash, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy. In contrast, infections acquired during childbirth, such as HSV and group B streptococcus, are more likely to cause meningitis and sepsis. Clinical presentation can include irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting.  

Option Analysis

✅ In utero infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intrapartum infection:
Incorrect: Infection by the herpes simplex virus and group B streptococcus can occur during the intrapartum period. Clinical presentation may include irritability, vomiting, and poor feeding, suggestive of underlying meningitis or sepsis. In contrast, intrapartum infections would not account for this patient’s cataracts, hearing loss, or heart murmur.  
❌ Postpartum infection:
Incorrect: This patient has hearing loss, cataracts, and a heart murmur, concerning congenital rubella infection. In contrast, postpartum rubella infections are often asymptomatic or can cause mild symptoms such as fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy.  
❌ Maternal alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is caused by alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Clinical symptoms include characteristic facial abnormalities such as a smooth philtrum, small palpebral fissures, and a thin vermillion border. FAS is not commonly associated with cataracts.  
❌ Folate deficiency:
Incorrect: Folate deficiency can cause neural tube defects such as spina bifida and myelomeningocele. However, this patient’s constellation of cataracts, hearing loss, and heart murmur suggests congenital rubella infection than in utero folate deficiency.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for the evaluation of absent menses. The patient has not had a menstrual period yet but is otherwise healthy. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows appropriate breast development and growth of pubic and underarm hair. The patient declined a vaginal exam. Karyotype analysis reveals 46 XX. Pregnancy test is negative; thyroid stimulating hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are normal. Pelvic ultrasound shows 2 normal-sized ovaries but no uterus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Defective conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with primary amenorrhea, normal development of secondary sexual characteristics, and an absent uterus is consistent with Müllerian agenesis.

Müllerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome, results from the failure of mullerian duct development. The Müllerian duct system is responsible for the development of the uterus, cervix and upper two thirds of the vagina, so these organs may be absent, or rudimentary and obstructed, which explains the absence of menses. The ovaries develop normally in these individuals, and the ovarian follicles make normal amounts of estrogen and progesterone; therefore, patients develop normal secondary sexual characteristics (e.g., breast development, axillary and public hair). FSH and LH levels are also within normal limits.



Option Analysis

❌ Defective conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone:
Incorrect: 5-alpha reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Deficiency of this enzyme causes female external genitalia and male internal genitalia to develop. Such patients have a male karyotype (i.e 46 XY). This patient’s karyotype reveals 46 XX, and she has female internal genitalia (ovaries).
❌ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone deficiency:
Incorrect:  Kallman syndrome, an X-linked disorder resulting from the failure of migration of fetal olfactory and GnRH producing neurons, causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Secondary sexual characteristics are not well developed (unlike this patient with normal breasts and pubic hair).
✅ Failure of mullerian duct formation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of an X chromosome:
Incorrect: Turner syndrome results from nondisjunction of sex chromosomes during meiosis. The patients have low estrogen levels leading to amenorrhea and absent breast development. Pelvic ultrasound shows small ovaries (unlike the normal sized ovaries seen in this patient).
❌ Defect in androgen receptor function:
Incorrect: Androgen insensitivity syndrome results from a defect in androgen receptor function. Although the patients do not have a uterus, pubic and axillary hair are also absent. Moreover, such patients are karyotypically male (i.e 46 XY).

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the physician accompanied by his parent for a routine visit. The patient has repeatedly failed reading comprehension and mathematics tests in school. The patient was born at an advanced maternal age of 42. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is at the 89th percentile for height. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have gynecomastia, long extremities, and testicular hypoplasia. A mid-systolic click is auscultated most prominently over the cardiac apex. Which of the following best describes this patient’s chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
This patient exhibits poor school performance, gynecomastia, long extremities, testicular hypoplasia, and mitral valve prolapse (as evidenced by the mid-systolic click). He was born to a mother with advanced maternal age (age 36 and higher). In combination, these findings are concerning for Klinefelter syndrome (XXY).  

Advanced maternal age is a major risk factor for the development of chromosomal abnormalities. Studies have demonstrated that as women become older, age-dependent changes in the sister chromatid cohesion complex that form during meiosis I are responsible for aberrancies in chromosomal translocation. Specifically, proteins responsible for pairing the chromatids, such as SMC1 Beta, have decreased function with advanced maternal age.  

 There are five main chromosomal disorders associated with advanced maternal age, and they include the trisomies (21, 18, and 13), Triple X syndrome, and Klinefelter syndrome. Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common autosomal chromosome abnormality associated with increased maternal age.  

 There are four main chromosomal abnormalities associated with the sex chromosomes. These include Klinefelter syndrome, Turner syndrome, Triple X syndrome (XXX), and Jacobs syndrome (XYY). Among these four disorders, Klinefelter Syndrome is the most prevalent.  

Of note, Turner syndrome and Jacobs syndrome are typically caused by meiotic nondisjunction of the paternal gametes. As a result, these conditions are not associated with advanced maternal age.  

Option Analysis

❌ Trisomy 21  :
 Incorrect: Down syndrome is the most common chromosomal abnormality associated with advanced maternal age. The condition can also present with intellectual disability. However, this patient has long limbs, gynecomastia, and a cardiac murmur suggestive of mitral valve prolapse. In combination, these findings are more suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome (XXY).  
❌ XXX:
 Incorrect: Individuals with triple X syndrome have a female phenotype. The condition can range from being asymptomatic to presenting with an unusually tall stature, developmental delays, and learning disabilities. In contrast, the child in this vignette is phenotypically male.   
❌ XO:
 Incorrect: Turner syndrome presents with delayed puberty, short stature, heart defects, infertility, and learning disabilities. Individuals with Turner syndrome will have a female phenotype. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has tall stature and a male phenotype.   
✅ XXY:
 Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ XYY:
 Incorrect: XYY syndrome, also termed double Y syndrome and Jacobs syndrome, is not the same as Klinefelter syndrome, although the two are quite similar. XYY syndrome can present with tall stature, intellectual disability, and severe acne. However, XYY syndrome would not typically cause small testicles or mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: A 10-day-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician for his first newborn evaluation. Since birth, he has had persistent swelling of his scrotum. He was born at 39 weeks gestation following an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. He has been breastfeeding multiple times throughout the day and is making 8-9 wet diapers a day with normal stooling. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral descended testicles that are palpable in the scrotum. There is a visibly enlarged, fluctuant left hemiscrotum. A penlight is held behind the left hemiscrotum, which demonstrates transillumination. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Patent processus vaginalis with peritoneal communication
Excessive production of fluid from the tunica vaginalis
Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal
Impaired lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures
Malignant proliferation of testicular germ cells

questions.solution:
A hydrocele is an abnormal collection of serous fluid between the two layers (visceral and parietal) of the tunica vaginalis of the testis.

There are four mechanisms that may result in the development of a hydrocele:

  1.  Connection with the peritoneal cavity through a patent processus vaginalis (congenital) 
  2.  Excessive production of fluid by the visceral and parietal layers of the tunica vaginalis (secondary hydrocele) 
  3.  Defective absorption of fluid by the parietal layer of the tunica vaginalis 
  4.  Impaired lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures, such as in filarial hydroceles 
This neonate likely has a congenital hydrocele, which results from failure of the processus vaginalis to obliterate. During development, the testes are formed retroperitoneally and descend into the scrotum via the inguinal canal. Normally, the proximal portion of the processus vaginalis obliterates while the distal portion persists as the tunica vaginalis. Therefore, the tunica vaginalis becomes a potential space for fluid collection. In the case of a patent processus vaginalis, peritoneal fluid is allowed to move into the scrotum, forming a hydrocele.

A characteristic feature of hydroceles is their ability to transilluminate. An ultrasound, although not necessary for diagnosis, typically reveals an anechoic or echolucent area surrounding the testis. Most primary causes of hydrocele require no surgery. Congenital hydroceles tend to resolve spontaneously by the end of the first year of life.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Patent processus vaginalis with peritoneal communication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Excessive production of fluid from the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Inflammatory intrascrotal conditions, such as epididymitis and/or orchitis can lead to secondary or reactive hydroceles, caused by excessive fluid production from the mesothelial lining of the tunica vaginalis. This healthy-appearing neonate has no signs of an inflammatory process, making this etiology less likely.
❌ Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal:
Incorrect: This answer describes an inguinal hernia. Physical examination usually reveals an inguinal mass that is worsened with increased abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, Valsalva maneuver) and may extend to the scrotum; however, hernias do not transilluminate, making this etiology less likely.
❌ Impaired lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures:
Incorrect: Interference with the lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures can be seen in filarial hydroceles. Bancroftian filariasis is a mosquito-borne parasitic disease. In filarial hydroceles, the parasitic organisms obstruct the fluid absorption by the draining lymphatic vessels of the parietal layer (part of the tunica vaginalis), resulting in fluid accumulation and subsequent formation of a hydrocele. This child has no risk factors for acquiring filarial hydrocele, making this etiology unlikely.
❌ Malignant proliferation of testicular germ cells:
Incorrect: Testicular germ cell tumors can be seen in neonates. Patients typically have evidence of a palpable testicular lump; however, tumors do not transilluminate.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office with her mother for a routine health checkup. The patient has not had a menstrual period yet but is otherwise healthy.  She wears corrective spectacles for myopia. The patient performs well academically and plays the flute in her school’s marching band. The patient’s height and weight are at 5th and 60th percentile, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 150/85 mmHg in the right upper arm and 90/65 mmHg in the left upper arm. Physical examination shows a Tanner stage I breast with widely-spaced nipples. Serum FSH is 65 mU/mL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This adolescent has primary amenorrhea, which is defined as absence of menses at age 13 years in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics (i.e. Tanner stage I breast). This finding, in combination with short stature, widely spaced nipples, and elevated FSH levels, is consistent with Turner syndrome (TS).

Turner syndrome is a sporadic chromosomal disorder that usually results from nondisjunction of sex chromosomes during meiosis. Roughly half of the individuals have a 45, X0 karyotype, whereas the other half have a mosaic of either 45 X0 and 46 XX or a mosaic of 45 X0 and 46 XY. The syndrome is characterized by short stature, a wide or webbed neck, a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, low-set ears, as well as arms that turn outward at the elbows. The patients have low estrogen levels due to the loss of ovarian function, leading to amenorrhea and absent breast development. Low estrogen levels prevent negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis, leading to increased FSH and LH production.



The adrenal glands, however, are not affected, and thus the patients can have normal adrenarche. Additional features can include coarctation of aorta (which can cause asymmetric blood pressures), bicuspid aortic valve, horseshoe kidneys, hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.   

Option Analysis

❌ Severe calorie restriction and deficiency:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea occurs in females with severe calorie restriction and nutrient deficiency due to the suppression of hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. FSH and LH are low in this condition. This patient’s FSH is elevated.
✅ Loss of an X chromosome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Failure of mullerian duct formation:
Incorrect: Failure of mullerian duct formation results in mullerian agenesis. This condition is characterized by the failure of the formation of the uterus, cervix and upper vagina.  Patients usually have normal secondary sexual characteristics (e.g. breast development and normal stature). Ovarian development is normal.
❌ Failure of follicle maturation:
Incorrect: The imbalance of LH/FSH ratio in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can result in the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. PCOS is characterized by hyperandrogenism (e.g. acne and hirsutism) or biochemically with elevated testosterone levels. Menstrual irregularities and infertility can also be seen. Ovaries appear polycystic on ultrasound.
❌ Congenital GnRH deficiency:
Incorrect: Kallman syndrome, an X-linked disorder, results from the failure of migration of fetal olfactory and GnRH producing neurons, leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Serum FSH and LH levels are decreased (unlike this patient).

questions.text: A 5-month-old female infant is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit for surgical treatment of preductal coarctation of the aorta. The patient is stable and afebrile. Blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 34/min. During subsequent evaluation, the patient is found to have a horseshoe kidney as well as lymphedema affecting the hands and feet. The patient has low set ears. Which of the following is the most likely genetic aberration that led to this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Partial loss of chromosome during mitosis

questions.solution:
This vignette describes a female infant with several congenital anomalies, namely preductal coarctation of the aorta, horseshoe kidney, and lymphedema. These findings are suggestive of Turner syndrome.  

Answering this question requires an understanding of the different types of chromosomal abnormalities present within Turner syndrome (see table below). A complete lack of Y chromosomal inheritance, which often occurs due to a nondisjunction during meiosis of the paternal gamete, would lead to the 45 XO genotype. Affected patients will present with the most severe form of Turner syndrome and likely have multiple congenital anomalies, as in the case of this patient.  

In contrast, if Turner syndrome were to develop due to nondisjunction during mitosis, then chromosomal mosaicism would develop. Chromosomal mosaicism means that different cells in the patient’s body will have varying genotypes (e.g., 45 XO, 46 XX).  

Clinical features of Turner syndrome include a female phenotype with webbed neck, shield chest, short stature, lymphedema, nail dysplasia, and high-arched palate. Turner syndrome presents with gonadal dysgenesis and streak ovaries, which results in insufficient estrogen production. As a result, patients can have delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, osteoporosis, and infertility. Furthermore, patients are at risk for coarctation of the aorta and renal malformations.  



Option Analysis

✅ Nondisjunction event during meiosis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nondisjunction event during mitosis  :
Incorrect: While this event would also result in Turner syndrome, it would result in a mosaic form of the condition. The mosaic form of Turner syndrome has far less severe symptoms due to the expression of normal 46 XX chromosomes in some cells. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has multiple congenital abnormalities and likely has a uniform genotype of 45 XO within all cells.
❌ Partial loss of chromosome during mitosis  :
Incorrect: This event would also result in a mosaic form of Turner syndrome, which is far less severe due to the expression of normal 46 XX chromosomes in some cells. This patient has the severe form, as demonstrated by the multiple congenital abnormalities, and likely has a uniform genotype of 45 XO within all cells.  
❌ Nondisjunction resulting in Trisomy 21   :
Incorrect: Individuals with Trisomy 21 can present with low set ears, a single palmar crease, short ears, and short neck. While individuals with trisomy 21 may develop cardiac defects (e.g. atrioventricular septal defects), the condition is not typically associated with coarctation of the aorta.  
❌ Nondisjunction resulting in Trisomy 18  :
Incorrect: Edwards syndrome can present with clenched hands, an abnormally small head, underdeveloped jaw, and rocker bottom feet. However, the condition would not typically present with the combination of coarctation of the aorta, lymphedema, and horseshoe kidney.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to abnormal tissue “coming out of her vagina.” The patient was born via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Vaccinations are up to date. She has reached all developmental milestones. There is no family history of genetic conditions or malignancy. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 105/68 mmHg. On physical examination, the child is playing comfortably and in no acute distress. Vaginal examination reveals multiple polyp-like structures protruding through the vaginal introitus. This lesion most likely derived from which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This patient has sarcoma botryoides, a subtype of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is a type of malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. The main subtypes include alveolar, embryonal, and pleomorphic. Most embryonal rhabdomyosarcomas are the sarcoma botryoides subtype.  

The name sarcoma botryoides derives from the Greek word botrys, which means “a bunch of grapes” due to its appearance. It is the most common vaginal malignancy in children and arises almost exclusively in girls younger than 5 years. It may also arise within the wall of the bladder. On histology, it is composed of rhabdomyoblasts arranged in sheets or nests. Rhabdomyosarcomas are aggressive tumors that usually require treatment with surgery and chemotherapy, with or without radiation therapy. The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is associated with the best prognosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Striated muscle:
 Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Smooth muscle :
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from smooth muscle include leiomyoma (benign) and leiomyosarcoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.  
❌ Stratified squamous :
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from stratified squamous cells include papilloma (benign), squamous cell carcinoma (malignant), and epidermoid carcinoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.  
❌ Melanocytes:
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from melanocytes include nevus (benign) and malignant melanoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.  
❌ Endothelium:
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from the endothelium lining of blood vessels include hemangioma (benign) and angiosarcoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravid woman has a stillbirth at 21-weeks of gestation. The patient has been consistent with her prenatal care and taking daily prenatal vitamins. She returned from a trip to Nigeria 6 months ago. Past medical history is notable for type I diabetes mellitus. She developed a fever, swollen lymph nodes, and muscle aches during the pregnancy that lasted for a week. A fetal autopsy is notable for scattered intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, macrocephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following maternal exposures most likely resulted in this fetus’s condition?
questions.solution:
The fetus’s autopsy demonstrates scattered intracranial calcifications, macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, and hepatosplenomegaly. Furthermore, the mother experienced mononucleosis-like symptoms during pregnancy. In combination, these findings are suggestive of congenital toxoplasmosis.

Toxoplasmosis gondii is an obligate intracellular protozoan that can cause maternal and fetal infection. The main source of maternal infection is contact with cat feces or ingestion of cysts found within undercooked meats and vegetables. The parasite can be vertically transmitted via the placenta from mother to fetus in the antenatal period.

Primary maternal infection can present nonspecific symptoms during pregnancy, such as self-limiting fever, lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis, and generalized muscle aches. High clinical suspicion of acute infection should prompt serological testing (e.g. IgG and IgM levels) for toxoplasmosis.

On the other hand, Congenital toxoplasmosis can present with chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and jaundice. Neuroimaging may reveal diffuse intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, and multiple ring-enhancing lesions.
 



Option Analysis

✅ Exposure to cats:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mosquito bites:
Incorrect: The Zika virus can be transmitted through sexual contact or a mosquito bite. It causes microcephaly, not macrocephaly.  
❌ Infected respiratory droplets:
Incorrect: Maternal infection with parvovirus B19 can be acquired through contact with respiratory droplets. In utero parvovirus infection can cause fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis but would not typically cause intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, macrocephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly.  
❌ Infected genital secretions:
Incorrect: Maternal syphilis infection can develop due to sexual intercourse and exposure to infected genital secretions. The spirochete can then infect the fetus and cause symptoms of congenital syphilis, including skeletal and ocular abnormalities and a maculopapular rash. However, congenital syphilis would not typically cause hydrocephalus.  
❌ Unpasteurized milk:
Incorrect: The bacteria Listeria monocytogenes can be transmitted via the consumption of unpasteurized dairy products. The pathogen causes listeriosis, leading to stillbirth, spontaneous abortion, and granulomatosis in antiseptic (presence of granulomas throughout the fetus’s body). However, listeriosis would not typically cause hydrocephalus or macrocephaly.

questions.text: A 28-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a routine evaluation. The patient was born via vaginal delivery at 38-weeks of gestational age. The patient’s mother received minimal antenatal care. During the third trimester of pregnancy, the mother had developed a disseminated maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles and arthralgias. The patient’s weight is at the 25th percentile, and head circumference is at the 50<sup>th</sup> percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. A depressed nasal bridge, malformed teeth, and bowing of the tibia are also observed. Cardiovascular examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This infant has a depressed nasal bridge, notching the incisors, bowing of the tibia, and hepatosplenomegaly. These findings are consistent with the clinical manifestations of congenital syphilis. Furthermore, the mother has a history of a maculopapular rash and arthralgias, indicating a maternal infection with secondary syphilis.

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum. During pregnancy, maternal syphilis infection produces symptoms similar to those in a non-pregnant adult. Symptoms may include a painless papule (primary syphilis), maculopapular rash, pharyngitis, mucocutaneous lesions (secondary syphilis), as well as cardiovascular and neurological involvement (tertiary syphilis).

Syphilis can be vertically transmitted via the placenta, resulting in congenital syphilis. Most neonates are asymptomatic at birth but can subsequently develop manifestations of congenital syphilis. Early symptoms (<2 years of age) include generalized lymphadenopathy, fever, and a maculopapular rash affecting the palms and soles. Later symptoms of congenital syphilis include dental deformities (Hutchinson teeth), skeletal abnormalities (anterior bowing of the tibia), hepatosplenomegaly, saddle nose deformity, and sensorineural hearing loss. Fortunately, congenital syphilis can be prevented via early screening, identification of maternal infection, and treatment with penicillin.
 



Option Analysis

✅ Spirochete bacteria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obligate intracellular protozoan:
Incorrect: Congenital toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan Toxoplasma gondii. The condition can lead to chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, microcephaly, and intracranial calcifications. In contrast, the facial features and bone abnormalities seen in this patient are not typically associated with congenital toxoplasmosis.  
❌ Enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus. Congenital CMV infection can lead to hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, and hearing loss. The characteristic facial features in this patient are not present in individuals with congenital CMV infection.  
❌ Enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: Maternal infection with rubella can present with a self-limited maculopapular rash and arthralgias. However, congenital rubella is characterized by cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and congenital heart defects. The absence of these findings in this patient makes the diagnosis of congenital rubella syndrome unlikely.  
❌ Gram-positive cocci in chains:
Incorrect: Neonates infected with group B streptococcus (GBS), which appears microscopically as chains of Gram-positive cocci, can present with sepsis, meningitis, and encephalitis. Fetuses can acquire GBS via exposure to vaginal bacteria during the childbirth process. However, GBS infection would not account for this patient's facial and tibial deformities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravid woman has a stillbirth at 23-weeks of gestation. Her prenatal care was inconsistent. She returned from a trip to Nigeria 2 months ago and has a history of type I diabetes mellitus. The patient works as a teacher at a daycare facility. She developed a fever, wrist pain, and ankle pain during the pregnancy that self-resolved after around two weeks. Fetal autopsy reveals hydrocephalus, bilateral pleural effusions, lung hypoplasia, and hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for the fetal demise?
questions.solution:
This fetus’s autopsy findings suggest hydrops fetalis, which is characterized by an abnormal collection of fluid within the fetal soft tissue and serous cavities (e.g., pericardium, pleural space, peritoneal cavity). This condition is associated with parvovirus B19 infection.

Parvovirus B19 is a single-stranded, non-enveloped DNA virus. It is a common cause of nonimmune fetal hydrops. The pathogen preferentially targets erythroid progenitor cells within the bone marrow and blood, resulting in the inhibition of erythropoiesis through cytotoxic effects. Since there are fewer red blood cells to carry oxygen, the heart will pump a larger blood volume to give the growing fetus the oxygen it needs. These changes increase intravascular pressure, cause fluid extravasation, and result in hydrops fetalis.

Parvovirus is commonly transmitted to the mother via respiratory droplets and subsequently vertically transmitted to the fetus. Maternal infection often results in a self-limited illness characterized by symmetrical arthralgias of the wrists, knees, and feet. Fetal infection can result in intrauterine fetal demise, hydrops fetalis, and miscarriage.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Parvovirus B19:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Treponema pallidum:
Incorrect: Treponemal palladium is a spirochete that can cause vertically transmitted infections. Clinical manifestations of congenital syphilis include rash, skeletal and dental abnormalities, hepatosplenomegaly, and rhinitis. Hydrops fetalis is uncommon.  
❌ Herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: The herpes simplex virus (HSV) can be sexually transmitted. Maternal infection would lead to painful, vesicular genital lesions. Vertical transmission of HSV to the fetus can cause microcephaly, skin vesicles, and microphthalmia. In contrast, hydrops fetalis is uncommon.  
❌ Toxoplasma gondii:
Incorrect: Toxoplasmosis can be vertically transmitted, and congenital infection is characterized by chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and intracranial calcifications. In contrast, hydrocephalus, bilateral pleural effusions, lung hypoplasia, and hepatosplenomegaly are not typically associated with congenital toxoplasmosis.  
❌ Norovirus:
Incorrect: Norovirus is responsible for rapid onset gastroenteritis outbreaks in child care facilities. It is not vertically transmitted and therefore would not cause fetal deformities.

questions.text:
A 1-week-old boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit due to fever, poor feeding, and irritability. The neonate was born at 37-weeks gestational age. During the third trimester of pregnancy, the patient’s mother had a self-limiting episode of gastroenteritis. Group B streptococcus screening at 36-weeks of gestation was negative. The family owns two cats. The patient’s weight is at the 20th percentile, and head circumference is at the 50th percentile. Temperature is 39.1°C (102°F), blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, and respiratory rate is 70/min. Physical examination reveals an irritable patient with bulging fontanelles. Scleral icterus is present, and jaundice is observed over the chest. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis is shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathogen likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
 
CSF Laboratory Value
Result
Cell count  
600/mm3
 (80% neutrophils)  
Glucose
25 mg/dL  
Protein
110 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This neonate presents fever, hypotension, irritability, and bulging fontanelles. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals pleocytosis with a neutrophil predominance, increased protein levels, and decreased glucose levels. In combination, these findings suggest neonatal sepsis secondary to bacterial meningitis. Listeria monocytogenes is a facultative intracellular, Gram-positive bacterium common cause of neonatal meningitis.

Listeria monocytogenes is a food-borne pathogen transmitted via the consumption of unpasteurized milk products and deli meats. Maternal infection by the bacterium causes fever, flu-like symptoms, and diarrhea. Maternal symptoms are generally self-limited. The organism can subsequently be vertically transmitted via the placenta to the fetus. Fetal complications from Listeria infection include multiorgan abscesses (termed granulomatosis infantiseptica), intrauterine fetal demise, premature labor, and neonatal sepsis.

Listeria meningitis can be diagnosed by isolating the organism via Gram stain and culture. Ampicillin can be used to treat the infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Facultative intracellular, Gram-positive rod:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enveloped, DNA virus:
Incorrect: The herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause meningoencephalitis that often affects the temporal lobes. CSF examination would reveal lymphocytic pleocytosis, the presence of red blood cells, and a normal glucose level. In contrast, this patient's CSF demonstrates neutrophil predominance and decreased glucose, suggesting a bacterial infection.  
❌ Intracellular parasite:
Incorrect: Congenital toxoplasmosis presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. The pathogen is acquired via contact with cat feces or ingestion of undercooked vegetables and meat. In contrast, this patient has a fever, bulging fontanelles, and CSF studies demonstrating an elevated cell count with neutrophil predominance, suggestive of meningitis. Toxoplasmosis is not a common cause of neonatal meningitis.  
❌ Gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Incorrect: Staphylococcal bacteria are not a common cause of neonatal meningitis. However, it can be implicated in meningitis following neurosurgical procedures.  
❌ Gram-negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Neisseria meningitidis is a common cause of meningitis in adults and children over 6-months of age. It is not a foodborne pathogen and does not commonly cause meningoencephalitis in neonates.

questions.text:
A 6-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department after an episode of generalized seizure. He has also experienced lethargy and poor feeding. The mother had limited access to prenatal care. The patient was delivered at home by a midwife. During the third trimester of pregnancy, the mother developed multiple painful genital lesions that persisted until labor. Temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, and respiratory rate is 37/min. Weight is at the 20th percentile, and head circumference is at the 40th percentile. The anterior fontanelle is open, and facial features appear normal. Ulcerative lesions are present over the tongue and oral mucosa. Examination of the skin is shown below. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis is notable for mononuclear pleocytosis and an elevated protein level. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
 
 Image reproduced from CDC Public Health Library
questions.solution:
This neonate presents with lethargy, irritability, seizures, and cutaneous vesicular lesions. Maternal history is notable for painful lesions isolated to the genitalia. In combination, these findings suggest neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

HSV is a sexually transmitted infection. Maternal infection by the virus is often asymptomatic but can sometimes manifest with multiple, painful genital lesions.

The virus can be vertically transmitted to the neonate via contact with infected vaginal secretions during delivery. Neonatal HSV infection presents characteristic vesicular skin lesions over the trunk, face, and axilla. Lesions can also be found within the oropharynx. Furthermore, neonatal HSV infection can lead to ocular involvement (e.g., optic atrophy, chorioretinitis) and meningoencephalitis (inflammation of the meninges and brain), manifest with seizures, hypothermia, and poor feeding.

In mothers with HSV lesions, acyclovir is recommended to treat the lesions and reduce the risk of neonatal infection. Cesarean delivery is generally recommended if active lesions are present at delivery, though it does not eliminate the risk of transmission.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Herpes simplex virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zika virus:
Incorrect: The Zika virus can be transmitted through sexual contact or a mosquito bite. It does not result in the development of a vesicular rash.  
❌ Varicella-zoster virus:
Incorrect: The maternal history of skin lesions isolated to the genitalia suggests infection by the herpes simplex virus transmitted to the neonate during delivery.  
❌ Facultative anaerobic bacterium:
Incorrect: Although clinical manifestations of herpes simplex neonatorum can be similar to neonatal bacterial sepsis, the patient’s cutaneous lesions suggest the former.  
❌ Obligate intracellular parasitic protozoan:
Incorrect: Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasitic protozoan. However, infection by this pathogen would not account for the vesicular skin lesions observed in this patient.
